Getting Started

Making a REST API call

The simplest way to get started is by making an actual API call. For example let’s list all the services you have on the gateway:

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/services

If you follow the link above you will be making a REST API call to list all the services in the gateway.

The URL

All the available api calls have a similar url format:

https://[gateway-host]/[restman-service]/[api-version]/[api-resource]

gateway-hostThis is the host and port that this gateway can be reached at
restman-serviceThis is the uri that the rest management service is published to.
Api-versionThis is the version of the api that you are accessing. All api calls will require an api version
Api-resourcethis is the resource that is being accessed. This can either map to an actual resource available on the gateway, like a policy or JDBCConnection, or it can reference an available service, like the migration service.

The Response

All API calls will return the results wrapped. The wrapper will be either a l7:List or l7:Item. These are both based on the same underlying object and so they both will have:

NameA nice human readable name of what this contains
IdThe id of the contained object
TypeThey type of item that this contains
TimeStampThe time that this item was created.
Link0 or more links. These are links related to the containing object

The List wrapper will also contain 0 or more Items. These items are the listing results

The Item wrapper will contain a single resource. This resource will be the object that this item wraps.

Setup

Setup from the Policy Manager

In order to install the Gateway REST Management Service from the Policy Manager follow these steps:

  1. Select Tasks -> Publish Internal Service from the menu
  2. In the "Publish Internal Service Wizard” select the “Gateway REST Management Service"
  3. Optionally, you can change to routing URI to something other than the default. However, the routing URI should always end with a '/*'
  4. Click finish to publish the Gateway REST Management Service. This will create a new service in the root folder called "Gateway REST Management Service"

Setup Using Auto-Provisioning

The Gateway REST Management service can be installed automatically on a new gateway using the auto-provisioning service.

A gateway can automatically install an internal service on startup if it is licensed and there are no other services installed (essentially a new gateway). This is done by providing a file in a folder on the gateway machine specifying the internal service to install. By default running this command on the gateway should set it up

touch /opt/SecureSpan/Gateway/node/default/etc/bootstrap/services/restman

Basic Entity Operations

Most of the entities support the same set of similar operations. These include the basic CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update and Delete) operations, Listing/Searching operations, and retrieving template (example) entities. The general use case for these operations is described below.

Listing and Searching Entities

You can list all entities of a given type by making a GET request to that entity’s URI. For example you can list all Folders on the gateway by making a request to https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders. This will return a List of Items representing all the folders on the gateway.

Listing Example

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders

Http Method

GET

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:List xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>FOLDER list</l7:Name>
    <l7:Type>List</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T15:27:30.386-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
    <l7:Item>
        <l7:Name>Root Node</l7:Name>
        <l7:Id>0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76</l7:Id>
        <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
        <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T15:27:30.384-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
        <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76"/>
        <l7:Resource>
            <l7:Folder id="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76" version="0">
                <l7:Name>Root Node</l7:Name>
            </l7:Folder>
        </l7:Resource>
    </l7:Item>
    <l7:Item>
        <l7:Name>My Services</l7:Name>
        <l7:Id>78457446b2cea4de5244873fe56a9f31</l7:Id>
        <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
        <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T15:27:30.385-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
        <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/78457446b2cea4de5244873fe56a9f31"/>
        <l7:Resource>
            <l7:Folder folderId="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76" id="78457446b2cea4de5244873fe56a9f31" version="0">
                <l7:Name>test</l7:Name>
            </l7:Folder>
        </l7:Resource>
    </l7:Item>
</l7:List>

The returned message above shows two folders. The Root Folder, this will always be present in a folder listing. There is also another folder called “My Services”.

The listing API call can also be used for searching and sorting entities. For example may entities have a name and in most cases you can find an entity by its name using the listing API call and providing a name parameter. For example you can find the folder called “My Services” using the following api call:

Listing Example 2

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders?name=My%20Services

Http Method

GET

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:List xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>FOLDER list</l7:Name>
    <l7:Type>List</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T15:27:30.386-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
    <l7:Item>
        <l7:Name>Root Node</l7:Name>
        <l7:Id>0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76</l7:Id>
        <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
        <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T15:27:30.384-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
        <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76"/>
        <l7:Resource>
            <l7:Folder id="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76" version="0">
                <l7:Name>Root Node</l7:Name>
            </l7:Folder>
        </l7:Resource>
    </l7:Item>
</l7:List>

The returned message is very similar to the one returned when listing all folders however only the folder with the name “My Services” is returned. You can specify multiple search parameters to create more complex searches. For example to list all enabled ssg connectors using protocol ‘HTTP’ or ‘FTP’: https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/ssgconnectors?enabled=true&protocol=HTTP&protocol=FTP

Listing results can also be sorted and ordered using ‘sort’ and ‘order’ query parameters. See the <WADL> or the <Resources> to find what you can sort and search by for an entity. For example you can sort all email listener in descending order by their host name: https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/emailListeners?sort=host&order=desc

If the returned list does not contain any items than none could be found with the specified search fields or you do not have the correct permissions to view the items. See <Authentication> for more info on authentication and permissions.

Retrieving an Entity

An individual entity can be returned by using its id. For example you can retrieve a secure password with id b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13052f72 by making the following api call:

Retrieving Example 1

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/passwords/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13052f72

Http Method

GET

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>MySecurePassword</l7:Name>
    <l7:Id>b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13052f72</l7:Id>
    <l7:Type>SECURE_PASSWORD</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:12:44.383-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/passwords/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13052f72"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/passwords/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/passwords"/>
    <l7:Resource>
        <l7:StoredPassword id="b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13052f72" version="1">
            <l7:Name>MySecurePassword</l7:Name>
            <l7:Properties>
                <l7:Property key="usageFromVariable">
                    <l7:BooleanValue>true</l7:BooleanValue>
                </l7:Property>
                <l7:Property key="description">
                    <l7:StringValue></l7:StringValue>
                </l7:Property>
                <l7:Property key="lastUpdated">
                    <l7:DateValue>2014-04-24T16:12:22.960-07:00</l7:DateValue>
                </l7:Property>
                <l7:Property key="type">
                    <l7:StringValue>Password</l7:StringValue>
                </l7:Property>
            </l7:Properties>
        </l7:StoredPassword>
    </l7:Resource>
</l7:Item>

Creating an Entity

In order to create an entity you POST the entity description to the entity's uri. All properties that are not in the entity description will be set to null. For example, to create a new folder

Creating Example 1

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders

Http Method

POST

Content-Type

application/xml

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Folder xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management" folderId="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76">
    <l7:Name>My New Folder</l7:Name>
</l7:Folder>

Response

Http Status

201

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>My New Folder</l7:Name>
    <l7:Id>b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c</l7:Id>
    <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:24:48.353-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
</l7:Item>

An entity can be created with a specific ID by using the PUT http method. See below on how to do that.

Updating an Entity

In order to update an entity you PUT the entity description to the entity's uri. All properties that are not in the entity description will be set to null. For example, to update the folder created above and change its name:

Updating Example

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c

Http Method

PUT

Content-Type

application/xml

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Folder xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management"
                    folderId="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76"
                    id="b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c"
                    version="0">
     <l7:Name>My Policies</l7:Name>
</l7:Folder>

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>My Policies</l7:Name>
    <l7:Id>b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c</l7:Id>
    <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:31:05.844-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a1305300c"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
</l7:Item>

You can create an entity with a specific ID by sending a PUT request to that entities URI. For example, to create a folder with the ID b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130530bf send the following request:

Creating Example 2

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130530bf

Http Method

PUT

Content-Type

application/xml

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Folder xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management" folderId="0000000000000000ffffffffffffec76" version="0">
     <l7:Name>My Encass Policies</l7:Name>
</l7:Folder>

Response

Http Status

201

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>My Encass Policies</l7:Name>
    <l7:Id>b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130530bf</l7:Id>
    <l7:Type>FOLDER</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:34:48.521-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130530bf"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/folders"/>
</l7:Item>

Not that when you all updating an entity all properties of that entity need to be in the entity description, even if they do not change. Otherwise they will be set to null.

Deleting an Entity

An entity can be deleted by sending a DELETE request to that entities URI. For example to delete a policy with id b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130531a0 send the following request:

Deleting Example

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/policies/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a130531a0

Http Method

DELETE

Response

Http Status

204

Retrieving an Entity Template

Most entities have a template uri that allows you to retrieve a template entity object. This can be used to then create a new entity. For example the template for cluster properties can be retrieved like this:

Template Example

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/clusterProperties/template

Http Method

GET

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>CLUSTER_PROPERTY Template</l7:Name>
    <l7:Type>CLUSTER_PROPERTY</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:44:56.440-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/clusterProperties/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="template" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/clusterProperties/template"/>
    <l7:Link rel="list" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/clusterProperties"/>
    <l7:Resource>
        <l7:ClusterProperty>
            <l7:Name>Template Cluster Property Name</l7:Name>
            <l7:Value>Template Cluster Property Value</l7:Value>
        </l7:ClusterProperty>
    </l7:Resource>
</l7:Item>

Other Operations

Dependency Analysis

Different entities depend on each other in many different ways. For example a Service can use a secure password, and a JDBC connection through the JDBC connection assertion.

The dependencies that a service, folder, policy, or encapsulated assertion has can be retrieved by using the dependency analysis sub-resource available on those resources.

For example you can get all the dependencies that a service has by making the following api call:

Dependency Example

Request

Uri

https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/services/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13053261/dependencies

Http Method

GET

Response

Http Status

200

Message Body

 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<l7:Item xmlns:l7="http://ns.l7tech.com/2010/04/gateway-management">
    <l7:Name>null dependencies</l7:Name>
    <l7:Type>Dependency</l7:Type>
    <l7:TimeStamp>2014-04-24T16:59:14.373-07:00</l7:TimeStamp>
    <l7:Link rel="self" uri="https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/services/b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13053261/dependencies"/>
    <l7:Resource>
        <l7:DependencyList>
            <l7:Options>
                <l7:Property key="returnAssertionsAsDependencies">
                    <l7:BooleanValue>false</l7:BooleanValue>
                </l7:Property>
            </l7:Options>
            <l7:Reference>
                <l7:Name>LookupInDatabase</l7:Name>
                <l7:Id>b0f109679d51ca3d3be3f08a13053261</l7:Id>
                <l7:Type>SERVICE</l7:Type>
                <l7:Dependencies>
                    <l7:Dependency>
                        <l7:Name>jdbc1</l7:Name>
                        <l7:Id>08d65a5a4449f13594a9379d1bb3820d</l7:Id>
                        <l7:Type>JDBC_CONNECTION</l7:Type>
                    </l7:Dependency>
                </l7:Dependencies>
            </l7:Reference>
            <l7:Dependencies>
                <l7:Dependency>
                    <l7:Name>pass1</l7:Name>
                    <l7:Id>08d65a5a4449f13594a9379d1bb38215</l7:Id>
                    <l7:Type>SECURE_PASSWORD</l7:Type>
                </l7:Dependency>
                <l7:Dependency>
                    <l7:Name>jdbc1</l7:Name>
                    <l7:Id>08d65a5a4449f13594a9379d1bb3820d</l7:Id>
                    <l7:Type>JDBC_CONNECTION</l7:Type>
                    <l7:Dependencies>
                        <l7:Dependency>
                            <l7:Name>pass1</l7:Name>
                            <l7:Id>08d65a5a4449f13594a9379d1bb38215</l7:Id>
                            <l7:Type>SECURE_PASSWORD</l7:Type>
                        </l7:Dependency>
                    </l7:Dependencies>
                </l7:Dependency>
            </l7:Dependencies>
        </l7:DependencyList>
    </l7:Resource>
</l7:Item>

The Dependency list response lists all the dependencies of an entity. The Reference is the entity that this dependency list is for. This reference contains:

NameThis is a human readable name for the entity.
IdThe id of the entity
TypeThe type of the entity
DependenciesThis is a list of the direct dependencies that this entity has.
Link0 or more links. These are links related to the containing object

Following the Reference is a list of dependencies. This is a list of all the dependencies, both direct and indirect, that this reference has. Each dependency contains:

NameThis is a human readable name for the entity.
IdThe id of the entity
TypeThe type of the entity
DependenciesThis is a list of the direct dependencies that this entity has.
Link0 or more links. These are links related to the containing object

Migration

The migration resource can be used to migrate folders, services, and policies between gateways. See more information about using the migration resource here: https://$#{host}:$#{port}/$#{service-url}/1.0/doc/migration.html
